U.S. Energy Information Administration - EIA - Independent Statistics and Analysis
  • Sources & Uses

    • Petroleum & Other Liquids

    Crude oil, gasoline, heating oil, diesel, propane, and other liquids including biofuels and natural gas liquids.

    Natural Gas

    Exploration and reserves, storage, imports and exports, production, prices, sales.

    Electricity

    Sales, revenue and prices, power plants, fuel use, stocks, generation, trade, demand & emissions.

    Consumption & Efficiency

    Energy use in homes, commercial buildings, manufacturing, and transportation.

    Coal

    Reserves, production, prices, employ- ment and productivity, distribution, stocks, imports and exports.

    Renewable &
    Alternative Fuels

    Includes hydropower, solar, wind, geothermal, biomass and ethanol.

    Nuclear & Uranium

    Uranium fuel, nuclear reactors, generation, spent fuel.
     

    Total Energy

    Comprehensive data summaries, comparisons, analysis, and projections integrated across all energy sources.

    Highlights

    This Week in Petroleum › Weekly Petroleum Status Report › Weekly Natural Gas Storage Report › Natural Gas Weekly Update › Electric Power Monthly › Quarterly Coal Report › Monthly Energy Review › Residential Energy Consumption Survey 2009 › Electricity Data Browser ›
  • Topics

    • Analysis & Projections

    Monthly and yearly energy forecasts, analysis of energy topics, financial analysis, Congressional reports.

    Markets & Finance

    Financial market analysis and financial data for major energy companies.

    Environment

    Greenhouse gas data, voluntary report- ing, electric power plant emissions.

    Highlights

    Short-Term Energy Outlook › Annual Energy Outlook › Energy Disruptions › International Energy Outlook › Excel Data Add-In ›
  • Geography

    • U.S. States

    State energy information, including overviews, rankings, data, and analyses.

    Maps

    Maps by energy source and topic, includes forecast maps.

    International

    International energy information, including overviews, rankings, data, and analyses.

    Highlights

    State Energy Data System (SEDS) › International Energy Statistics › Gulf of Mexico › U.S. Energy
    Mapping System ›

Radio Spots

Ready-to-broadcast news stories. Transcripts provided so radio spots can be re-recorded in whole or in part.

U.S. diesel fuel prices continue to decrease mp3
Date: January 30, 2017
Description: The U.S. average retail price for on-highway diesel fuel fell to $2.56 a gallon on Monday. That’s down 7-tenths of a penny from a week ago, based on the weekly price survey by the U.S. Energy Information Administration.
Contact/Author: Amerine Woodyard, 202-586-1256
Transcript: http://www.eia.gov/radio/transcript/diesel_price_01302017.pdf
Length of mp3: 00:00:33
Size of mp3: 0.5 mb
More on this topic: http://www.eia.gov/petroleum/gasdiesel/
U.S. gasoline prices continue to decrease (long version) mp3
Date: January 30, 2017
Description: The U.S. average retail price for regular gasoline fell to $2.30 a gallon on Monday. That’s down 3 cents from a week ago, based on the weekly price survey by the U.S. Energy Information Administration.
Contact/Author: Amerine Woodyard, 202-586-1256
Transcript: http://www.eia.gov/radio/transcript/gasoline_price_01302017_long.pdf

Residential heating oil price decreases mp3
Date: January 25, 2017
Description: The U.S. average retail price of home heating oil fell half of a cent from a week ago to $2.63 per gallon. That's up 57 cents from a year ago, based on the residential heating fuel survey by the U.S. Energy Information Administration.
Contact/Author: Jonathan Cogan, 202-586-8719

Residential heating oil price decreases mp3
Date: January 19, 2017
Description: The average retail price for home heating oil fell 7-tenths of a cent from a week ago to $2.64 per gallon. That's up 52 cents from a year ago, based on the residential heating fuel survey by the U.S. Energy Information Administration. Heating oil prices in the New England region remained at $2.60 per gallon, up 54 cents from a year ago.
Contact/Author: Marcela Rourk, 202-586-4412

Date: January 19, 2017
Description: The average retail price for propane is $2.33 per gallon, up 2.8 cents from last week, based on the residential heating fuel survey by the U.S. Energy Information Administration. Propane prices in the Midwest region averaged $1.77 per gallon, up two and a half cents from last week, and up 29.2 cents from a year ago.

U.S. crude oil production increasing again mp3
Date: January 10, 2017
Description: The general decline in U.S. crude oil production that began almost two years ago is likely over, as output is on the rise again as a result of more rigs drilling for oil and improved efficiencies from those rigs. In its new short-term forecast, the U.S. Energy Information Administration estimates that domestic oil production began increasing during the last three months of 2016. If confirmed when the final data are in, it would mark the first quarterly production increase since the first three months of 2015. Most of the growth in oil output during the last quarter of 2016 came from drilling in the federal waters of the Gulf of Mexico, according to EIA. Higher average oil prices in 2017 compared with last year are expected to support more production in the coming months. U.S. oil production is expected to average 9 million barrels per day in 2017, up slightly from last year, and then keep rising to 9.3 million barrels per day in 2018.
Contact/Author: Jonathan Cogan, 202-586-8719
Transcript: http://www.eia.gov/radio/transcript/steo_crude_oil_production_01102017.pdf
Length of mp3: 00:01:03
Size of mp3: 1.2 mb
More on this topic: http://www.eia.gov/outlooks/steo/report/
U.S. natural gas production expected to hit record highs in 2017 and 2018 mp3
Date: January 10, 2017
Description: U.S. annual natural gas production is expected to increase during each of the next two years after declining in 2016 for the first time in more than a decade. In its new short-term forecast, the U.S. Energy Information Administration said domestic natural gas production is expected to rise 2.2% in 2017 and increase 4.1% in 2018. Higher natural gas prices are mainly behind the boost in production. In addition to higher production, U.S. natural gas exports are also expected to increase over the next two years, as several liquefied natural gas export terminals come online. The United States is expected to export more natural gas than it imports on an annual basis during 2018, with net exports averaging 600 million cubic feet per day.
Contact/Author: Jonathan Cogan, 202-586-8719
Transcript: http://www.eia.gov/radio/transcript/steo_natural_gas_production_01102017.pdf
Length of mp3: 00:00:54
Size of mp3: 1.0 mb
More on this topic: http://www.eia.gov/outlooks/steo/report/
U.S. coal-fired electricity generation takes the lead in 2017 mp3
Date: January 10, 2017
Description: The amount of U.S. electricity generated from natural gas exceeded output from coal-fired power plants for the first time on an annual basis during 2016, but that trend is expected to reverse in 2017, as higher natural gas prices contribute to rising coal-fired generation. In its new short-term forecast, the U.S. Energy Information Administration expects coal will account for about one-third of electricity generation this year, edging out natural gas. However, natural gas is expected to take the lead again in electricity generation during 2018. The share of generation from nuclear energy is expected to decline to around 19% in 2018 after several nuclear power reactors are retired. Meanwhile, hydropower, solar, wind, and other renewables are forecast to increase to about 16% of U.S. electricity generation in 2018.
Contact/Author: Jonathan Cogan, 202-586-8719
Transcript: http://www.eia.gov/radio/transcript/steo_electricity_generation_01102017.pdf
Length of mp3: 00:00:57
Size of mp3: 1.2 mb
More on this topic: http://www.eia.gov/outlooks/steo/report/

Date: January 5, 2016
Description: The average retail price for home heating oil rose four and a half cents from a week ago to $2.63 per gallon. That's up 45 cents from a year ago, based on the residential heating fuel survey by the U.S. Energy Information Administration. Heating oil prices in the New England region rose to $2.59 per gallon, up 4.1 cents from last week, and up 45.1 cents from a year ago.

Propane prices in the Midwest region averaged $1.59 per gallon, up 4.3 cents from last week, and up 15.1 cents from a year ago.

Size of mp3: 0.1 mb
More on this topic: http://www.eia.gov/petroleum/heatingoilpropane/
U.S. monthly coal production tops 70 million tons for third time in 2016 mp3
Date: December 6, 2016
Description: U.S. monthly coal production topped 70 million short tons in November for the third time this year. In its new monthly forecast, the U.S. Energy Information Administration said domestic coal production reached almost 71 million tons during November. While that's higher than monthly output from a year earlier, total U.S. coal production is still expected to decline 15% in 2016 to the lowest level since 1978. For 2017, domestic coal production is forecast to increase 2%. November's strong coal production comes as more electricity is expected to be generated from coal than from natural gas this winter.
Contact/Author: Jonathan Cogan, 202-586-8719
Transcript: http://www.eia.gov/radio/transcript/steo_coal_production_12062016.pdf
Length of mp3: 00:00:43
Size of mp3: 0.9 mb
More on this topic: http://www.eia.gov/outlooks/steo/report/
Higher oil price could result in quicker U.S. oil production growth in 2017 mp3
Date: December 6, 2016
Description: If oil prices stay above $50 per barrel in the months ahead, that could result in quicker oil production growth in the United States during 2017. In its new monthly forecast, the U.S. Energy Information Administration said OPEC's recent decision to trim some of its oil production could push oil prices higher. If that happens, production could increase in some U.S. regions that have tight oil, such as the Permian Basin in west Texas and southeastern New Mexico. EIA said that U.S. oil production has been more resilient than expected to the low oil prices seen over the last year and a half. Higher oil prices would improve profits at U.S. oil companies, which could result in more investment to expand oil production in 2017 and beyond. Oil prices above $50 could also encourage major oil producing countries that are not members of OPEC to boost their output.
Contact/Author: Jonathan Cogan, 202-586-8719
Transcript: http://www.eia.gov/radio/transcript/steo_oil_production_12062016.pdf
Length of mp3: 00:00:57
Size of mp3: 1.2 mb
More on this topic: http://www.eia.gov/outlooks/steo/report/
Stronger global economy leading to higher oil demand growth in 2017 mp3
Date: December 6, 2016
Description: A stronger economy in the United States and in other countries will lead to higher global oil demand during 2017 than previously expected. In its new monthly forecast, the U.S. Energy Information Administration said global oil use is expected to increase by 1.6 million barrels per day next year. EIA noted that four major manufacturing regions of the world the United States, Europe, China, and India are all reporting growth. And an expanding manufacturing sector usually leads to more consumption of petroleum fuels, the agency said. A growing manufacturing sector can also indicate domestic and international demand for goods is increasing, which can lead to both future economic growth and higher oil demand.
Contact/Author: Jonathan Cogan, 202-586-8719
Transcript: http://www.eia.gov/radio/transcript/steo_oil_demand_12062016.pdf
Length of mp3: 00:00:49
Size of mp3: 1.0 mb
More on this topic: http://www.eia.gov/outlooks/steo/report/

Length of mp3: 00:00:25
Size of mp3: 0.4 mb
More on this topic: http://www.eia.gov/petroleum/heatingoilpropane/
U.S. natural gas production expected to rise in 2017 after declining in 2016 mp3
Date: November 8, 2016
Description: U.S. annual natural gas production is expected to decline in 2016 for the first time in more than a decade, but increase next year as drilling activity picks up. In its new monthly forecast, the U.S. Energy Information Administration said domestic natural gas output in 2016 is expected to be down 1.4 billion cubic feet per day from last year’s level. That would be the first annual decline in production since 2005. However, output is forecast to rise by almost 3 billion cubic feet per day in 2017 from this year’s production level and top 80 billion cubic feet per day on an annual basis for the first time ever. EIA said it expects that increased drilling activity and new pipelines connecting production to demand centers will reverse the decline in production in 2017.
Contact/Author: Jonathan Cogan, 202-586-8719
Transcript: http://www.eia.gov/radio/transcript/steo_natural_gas_production_11082016.pdf
Length of mp3: 00:00:56
Size of mp3: 0.9 mb
More on this topic: http://www.eia.gov/forecasts/steo/report/
Gasoline prices expected to fall below $2 per gallon in January on lower oil prices and lower seasonal demand mp3
Date: November 8, 2016
Description: Falling crude oil prices along with refiners making less expensive winter-blend gasoline and the normal seasonal decline in motor fuel demand are expected to push the average pump price for gasoline below $2 per gallon in January. In its new monthly forecast, the U.S. Energy Information Administration said drivers are expected to pay an average of $1.97 per gallon to fill up at the beginning of 2017. That’s a decline of more than 20 cents from the national average price of $2.18 per gallon forecast for November. Total U.S. gasoline consumption is expected to reach a record 9.3 million barrels per day this year because of a combination of low gasoline prices, higher employment, and a strong economy.
Contact/Author: Jonathan Cogan, 202-586-8719
Transcript: http://www.eia.gov/radio/transcript/steo_gasoline_price_11082016.pdf
Length of mp3: 00:00:50
Size of mp3: 0.8 mb
More on this topic: http://www.eia.gov/forecasts/steo/report/
U.S. oil production forecast revised up for 2016 and 2017 mp3
Date: November 8, 2016
Description: U.S. crude oil production is expected to be higher this year and in 2017 than previously forecast, because of a slower decline in onshore production. In its new monthly forecast, the U.S. Energy Information Administration revised up its estimate for domestic oil production by about 110,000 barrels per day for 2016 and by 150,000 barrels per day next year. EIA said increased drilling activity in the Permian Basin area located in West Texas and southeastern New Mexico and rising offshore oil output in the Gulf of Mexico is expected to partially offset declining production in other areas of the lower 48 states. The number of active rigs in the Permian region drilling for oil is almost equal to the combined rig count for the rest of the onshore and offshore areas in the United States. Although total U.S. oil production has been revised upward, annual output this year will still be about 600,000 barrels per day less than in 2015, which had the highest yearly production since the early 1970s.
Contact/Author: Jonathan Cogan, 202-586-8719
Transcript: http://www.eia.gov/radio/transcript/steo_crude_oil_production_11082016.pdf
Length of mp3: 00:01:09
Size of mp3: 1.0 mb
More on this topic: http://www.eia.gov/forecasts/steo/report/

Residential heating oil price increases mp3
Date: October 26, 2016
Description: The average retail price for home heating oil rose 1.2 cents from a week ago to $2.39 per gallon. That’s down 3 cents from a year ago, based on the residential heating fuel survey by the U.S. Energy Information Administration. Heating oil prices in the New England region rose to $2.33 per gallon, up 1.1 cents from last week, and down 3.9 cents from a year ago.
Contact/Author: Marcela Rourk, 202-586-4412
Transcript: http://www.eia.gov/radio/transcript/heating_oil_price_10262016.pdf
Length of mp3: 00:00:28
Size of mp3: 0.1 mb
More on this topic: http://www.eia.gov/petroleum/heatingoilpropane/

Date: October 26, 2016
Description: The average retail price for propane is $2.07 per gallon, up 1.4 cents from last week, based on the residential heating fuel survey by the U.S. Energy Information Administration. Propane prices in the Midwest region averaged $1.47 per gallon, up 1.5 cents from last week, and up 8.5 cents from a year ago.

Household heating bills expected to be higher than last winter, mainly driven by colder weather mp3
Date: October 13, 2016
Description: U.S. households are expected to pay higher heating bills this winter compared to last winter mainly because the weather is forecast to be colder than the relatively mild weather seen last winter and fuel prices are forecast to be higher.

Monthly gasoline price to dip below $2 this winter mp3
Date: October 13, 2016
Description: The nationwide average price for gasoline is expected to fall below $2 per gallon in January, as refiners have switched over to making the less expensive winter gasoline blend and because seasonal motor fuel consumption is typically lower than during the summer months.

U.S. diesel fuel prices continue to increase mp3
Date: October 11, 2016
Description: The U.S. average retail price for on-highway diesel fuel rose to $2.45 a gallon on Monday. That’s up 5.6 cents from a week ago, based on the weekly price survey by the U.S. Energy Information Administration. Diesel prices were highest in the West Coast states at 2.71 a gallon, up 5.4 cents from a week ago. Prices were lowest in the Gulf Coast states at 2.32 a gallon, up 6.7 cents.

Date: October 11, 2016
Description: The U.S. average retail price for regular gasoline rose to $2.27 a gallon on Monday. Decline in U.S. oil production won't be as steep mp3
Date: September 7, 2016
Description: Although total U.S. crude oil production is expected to continue declining, the drop in output this year and in 2017 won't be as steep, because of improved efficiency at drilling rigs and more drilling overall. In its new monthly forecast, the U.S. Energy Information Administration revised up its estimate for domestic daily oil output for this year by about 100,000 barrels to 8.8 million barrels per day. Daily production for next year was given a 200,000-barrel boost to 8.5 million barrels per day.
Contact/Author: Jonathan Cogan, 202-586-8719
Transcript: http://www.eia.gov/radio/transcript/steo_oil_production_09072016.pdf
Length of mp3: 00:00:56
Size of mp3: 0.9 mb
More on this topic: http://www.eia.gov/forecasts/steo/report/
Lower gasoline prices ahead mp3
Date: September 7, 2016
Description: U.S. retail gasoline prices are expected to continue falling through the end of 2016, even though gasoline demand is projected to remain strong. In its new monthly forecast, the U.S. Energy Information Administration said the average monthly price for regular-grade gasoline is expected to decline to $1.92 a gallon by December the lowest for the month in eight years.
Contact/Author: Jonathan Cogan, 202-586-8719
Transcript: http://www.eia.gov/radio/transcript/steo_gasoline_prices_09072016.pdf
Length of mp3: 00:00:44
Size of mp3: 0.7 mb
More on this topic: http://www.eia.gov/forecasts/steo/report/
Natural gas production on the rise mp3
Date: September 7, 2016
Description: After a brief slowdown in early 2016, U.S. natural gas production is expected to increase during the second half of this year and continue rising through 2017. In its new monthly forecast, the U.S. Energy Information Administration said domestic natural gas output during the fourth quarter of this year is expected to top 80 billion cubic feet per day and then climb to a new record of 82 billion cubic feet per day by end of 2017.
Contact/Author: Jonathan Cogan, 202-586-8719
Transcript: http://www.eia.gov/radio/transcript/steo_natural_gas_production_09072016.pdf
Length of mp3: 00:00:56
Size of mp3: 0.9 mb

U.S. diesel fuel prices increase for first time since June mp3
Date: August 22, 2016
Description: The U.S. average retail price for on-highway diesel fuel rose for the first time since June to $2.37 a gallon on Monday. That's up 6 cents from a week ago, based on the weekly price survey by the U.S. Energy Information Administration. Diesel prices were highest in the West Coast states at 2.62 a gallon, up 4 cents from a week ago. Prices were lowest in the Gulf Coast states at 2.25 a gallon, up 7 cents.

Date: August 22, 2016
Description: The U.S. average retail price for regular gasoline rose for the first time since June to $2.19 a gallon on Monday. That's up 4.4 cents from a week ago, based on the weekly price survey by the U.S. Energy Information Administration. Pump prices were highest in the West Coast states at 2.57 a gallon, up 3.9 cents from a week ago. Prices were lowest in the Gulf Coast states at 1.96 a gallon, up 2.6 cents.

Description: The U.S. average retail price for regular gasoline rose for the first time since June to $2.19 a gallon on Monday. That's up 4.4 cents from a week ago, based on the weekly price survey by the U.S. Energy Information Administration.

Gasoline prices peak, expected to fall through end of 2016 mp3
Date: July 12, 2016
Description: It’s all downhill for U.S. drivers at least far as the outlook for gasoline prices is concerned. Gasoline prices are expected to gradually fall through the end of this year. In its new monthly forecast, the U.S. Energy Information Administration said the retail price for regular-grade gasoline averaged $2.37 per gallon in June. That’s down 43 cents from the same month last year. The average monthly pump price is expected to drop to $2.01 per gallon in December. Gasoline prices are lower this year due to a combination of lower crude oil prices, high gasoline production, and rising gasoline inventories. Pump prices are lower even though annual U.S. gasoline demand in 2016 is on track to be the highest ever.
Contact/Author: Jonathan Cogan, 202-586-8719
Transcript: http://www.eia.gov/radio/transcript/steo_gasoline_price_07122016.pdf
Length of mp3: 00:00:49
Size of mp3: 0.8 mb
More on this topic: http://www.eia.gov/forecasts/steo/report/
Big drop in coal-fired electricity generation during first half of 2016 mp3
Date: July 12, 2016
Description: The amount of U.S. electricity generated by coal continues to decline in 2016, as power plant operators turn to more natural gas to produce electricity. In its new monthly forecast, the U.S. Energy Information Administration estimated that electricity generation by coal during the first half of this year fell 20% from the same period in 2015. By contrast, power generation by natural gas is nearly 7% higher so far this year. Sustained low natural gas prices resulting from high natural gas production and growing gas inventories…have led to increased use of natural gas for electricity generation. For the second half of 2016, EIA forecasts that natural gas generation will grow at a slower rate of 3.4%, while the amount of electricity generated by coal is expected to be about the same as during the second half of last year.
Contact/Author: Jonathan Cogan, 202-586-8719
Transcript: http://www.eia.gov/radio/transcript/steo_electricity_generation_07122016.pdf
Length of mp3: 00:00:58
Size of mp3: 0.9 mb
More on this topic: http://www.eia.gov/forecasts/steo/report/
U.S. natural gas exports to exceed imports for first time in 60 years mp3
Date: July 12, 2016
Description: The United States is on track during the second half of 2017 to export more natural gas than it imports for the first time since 1957. In its new monthly forecast, the U.S. Energy Information Administration said the United States will become a net exporter after years of steadily increasing its natural gas production and building the terminals necessary to ship super-cooled liquefied natural gas to overseas markets. Just last year, U.S. net imports of natural gas averaged 2.6 billion cubic feet per day. EIA expects natural gas production will rise this year and in 2017 in response to higher natural gas prices and more gas exports. Although exports are increasing, there are still expected to be abundant natural gas supplies to meet domestic demand. U.S. natural gas inventories are forecast to reach a record high of over 4 trillion cubic feet at the end of October.
Contact/Author: Jonathan Cogan, 202-586-8719
Transcript: http://www.eia.gov/radio/transcript/steo_natural_gas_exports_07122016.pdf
Length of mp3: 00:01:01
Size of mp3: 1.0 mb
More on this topic: http://www.eia.gov/forecasts/steo/report/

Higher crude oil prices contribute to higher summer gasoline prices mp3
Date: June 7, 2016
Description: The recent rise in crude oil prices will be passed on to consumers in the form of higher gasoline prices this summer but drivers will still find lower prices at the pump compared to what they paid last year. In its new monthly forecast, the U.S. Energy Information Administration said the retail price for regular-grade gasoline will average $2.27 per gallon this summer. That’s 6 cents higher than previously forecast but still down 36 cents from last year and the lowest summer price in 12 years. The average monthly price for gasoline is expected to peak in June at $2.36 per gallon and then drop to $2.21 in September. Higher crude oil prices which have almost doubled since beginning-of-the-year lows are pushing up the cost of gasoline. But that’s not expected to stop vacation travel as EIA forecasts gasoline demand will average a record 9.5 million barrels per day this summer.
Contact/Author: Jonathan Cogan, 202-586-8719
Transcript: http://www.eia.gov/radio/transcript/steo_gasoline_price_06072016.pdf
Length of mp3: 00:01:00
Size of mp3: 1.0 mb
More on this topic: http://www.eia.gov/forecasts/steo/report/
U.S. electricity generation from renewables to increase in 2016 mp3
Date: June 7, 2016
Description: The amount of U.S. electricity generated by hydropower, wind, solar, and other renewable energy sources is expected to grow in 2016. In its new monthly forecast, the U.S. Energy Information Administration said hydroelectric generation is expected to increase by 9.2% this year while wind power is forecast to grow by over 16% and solar power by 34%. All renewables combined are expected to account for 15% of total U.S. electricity generation in 2016. That’s up from about 13% last year. Fossil fuels will remain the dominant electricity generation fuel with natural gas accounting for about 34% of U.S. electricity generation during 2016 and coal for about 30%.
Contact/Author: Jonathan Cogan, 202-586-8719
Transcript: http://www.eia.gov/radio/transcript/steo_electricity_generation_06072016.pdf
Length of mp3: 00:00:52
Size of mp3: 0.9 mb
More on this topic: http://www.eia.gov/forecasts/steo/report/
Declines in U.S. monthly oil production expected to continue mp3
Date: June 7, 2016
Description: U.S. monthly oil production continues to decline in response to the drop in oil prices that began almost two years ago. In its new monthly forecast, the U.S. Energy Information Administration said domestic oil production averaged 8.7 million barrels per day in May falling below the daily output level of 9 million barrels for the first time since September 2014. May’s 250,000 barrel-per-day decrease in oil production would be the largest monthly drop in output since Hurricane Ike shut in offshore oil wells during September 2008. Looking ahead, EIA expects U.S. oil output to decline in most onshore production regions this year and into the second half of 2017 but expects increases in the Gulf of Mexico. Total U.S. oil production is expected to fall to an average of 8.1 million barrels per day in the third quarter of 2017 and then begin rising in response to forecasted oil price increases.
Contact/Author: Jonathan Cogan, 202-586-8719
Transcript: http://www.eia.gov/radio/transcript/steo_crude_oil_production_06072016.pdf
Length of mp3: 00:01:03
Size of mp3: 1.0 mb
More on this topic: http://www.eia.gov/forecasts/steo/report/

U.S. diesel fuel prices continue to increase mp3
Date: May 23, 2016
Description: The U.S. average retail price for on-highway diesel fuel rose to $2.36 a gallon on Monday. That's up 6 cents from a week ago, based on the weekly price survey by the U.S. Energy Information Administration.

More on this topic: http://www.eia.gov/petroleum/gasdiesel/
Summer gasoline price forecast slightly higher, but drivers still pay less than last year mp3
Date: May 10, 2016
Description: Rising crude oil prices are likely to be passed on to consumers at the pump, but U.S. drivers are still expected to pay the lowest summer gasoline prices since 2004, and for all of 2016 the average household will spend $900 less on gasoline than it did two years ago.” In its new monthly forecast, the U.S. Energy Information Administration said the retail price for regular grade gasoline will average $2.21 per gallon this summer. While that’s 17 cents higher than forecast last month it’s 42 cents lower than the price last summer. Rising crude oil prices which are up about 70% since hitting a 13-year low in February along with record high summer gasoline demand are behind the jump at the pump. The price of crude oil currently makes up almost half the cost of a gallon of gasoline. EIA expects the average monthly price for gasoline will peak at $2.28 per gallon in June and then to fall to $2.12 at the end of the summer driving season in September.
Contact/Author: Jonathan Cogan, 202-586-8719
Transcript: http://www.eia.gov/radio/transcript/steo_gasoline_price_05102016.pdf
Length of mp3: 00:01:06
Size of mp3: 1.0 mb
More on this topic: http://www.eia.gov/forecasts/steo/report/
Natural gas beats coal in power generation mp3
Date: May 10, 2016
Description: The amount of U.S. electricity generated by natural gas is expected to exceed the output from coal‐fired power plants this year and in 2017. In its new monthly forecast, the U.S. Energy Information Administration said natural gas's share of electricity generation in 2016 will be 34% while coal drops to slightly below 31%. Coal-fired power plants make somewhat of a comeback next year with a generation share of just over 31%. But that’s still below the 33% share for natural gas. High natural gas production and low natural gas prices have made coal a less competitive generating fuel for many U.S. power plant operators.
Contact/Author: Jonathan Cogan, 202-586-8719
Transcript: http://www.eia.gov/radio/transcript/steo_electricity_generation_05102016.pdf
Length of mp3: 00:00:45
Size of mp3: 0.8 mb
More on this topic: http://www.eia.gov/forecasts/steo/report/
Growth in global oil inventories slows, drawdown in stocks expected in late 2017 mp3
Date: May 10, 2016
Description: The growth in global oil inventories is expected to slow in response to stronger growth in world oil demand, with inventories now expected to be drawn down during the second half of next year. In its new monthly forecast, the U.S. Energy Information Administration said oil inventories will grow by just under 1 million barrels per day this year. Inventories will continue to grow during the first half of 2017 though at a decreasing rate before being drawn down by 100,000 barrels per day in the second half of next year. Higher global oil demand growth will be led by stronger fuel consumption in China and India. At the same time, world oil production is expected to increase at a slower rate than the increase in oil demand requiring a bite out of oil inventories in late 2017.
Contact/Author: Jonathan Cogan, 202-586-8719
Transcript: http://www.eia.gov/radio/transcript/steo_world_oil_inventories_05102016.pdf
Length of mp3: 00:00:52
Size of mp3: 0.9 mb
More on this topic: http://www.eia.gov/forecasts/steo/report/

U.S. summer gasoline prices dive this year mp3
Date: April 12, 2016
Description: Along with a dip in the pool, U.S. drivers could also enjoy a dip in gasoline prices this summer compared to last year. In its new monthly forecast, the U.S. Energy Information Administration said the price for regular-grade gasoline will average $2.04 per gallon this summer. That’s down about 60 cents from last year and the best summer deal at the pump in 12 years. Cheaper gasoline along with a stronger economy will encourage more driving. As a result, gasoline demand is forecast to reach a record high of nearly 9.5 million barrels per day this summer. Lower crude oil prices which are expected to be down about one‐third from last summer are behind the savings for consumers. Every $1 drop in the price of a barrel of oil translates into savings of almost 2.5 cents on the retail price of a gallon of gasoline. Cheaper gasoline will stretch beyond the summer months as 2016’s annual average pump price is forecast to come in at $1.94 per gallon. That will save the average U.S. household about $350 on gasoline this year compared to 2015.
Contact/Author: Jonathan Cogan, 202-586-8719
Transcript: http://www.eia.gov/radio/transcript/steo_gasoline_price_04122016.pdf
Length of mp3: 00:01:09
Size of mp3: 1.0 mb
More on this topic: http://www.eia.gov/forecasts/steo/report/
Less electricity use this summer slightly offset by higher power costs mp3
Date: April 12, 2016
Description: The average U.S. household will use less electricity this summer than last summer because of expected cooler temperatures, but slightly higher electricity prices means summer power bills won’t go down much. However, the outlook does vary across regions. Households in the South Atlantic states which includes Florida, Georgia, North Carolina, and Virginia will see the biggest savings. The average power bill in that region is expected to be down nearly 5% this summer. Meanwhile, households in the central Great Lakes area which includes Ohio, Illinois, Michigan, and Wisconsin could see a jump of more than 8% in their summer electricity bills. EIA forecasts that more electricity will be generated this year by natural gas, solar energy, and wind and less from coal-fired power plants.
Contact/Author: Jonathan Cogan, 202-586-8719
Transcript: http://www.eia.gov/radio/transcript/steo_electricity_generation_04122016.pdf
Length of mp3: 00:00:52
Size of mp3: 0.8 mb
More on this topic: http://www.eia.gov/forecasts/steo/report/
Natural gas inventories end the winter at a record high mp3
Date: April 12, 2016
Description: U.S. natural gas inventories finished the winter heating season at their highest level ever. In its new monthly forecast, the U.S. Energy Information Administration said natural gas stocks at the end of March stood at 2.478 trillion cubic feet. That’s slightly above the previous end-of-winter record set in 2012. This year’s natural gas inventories are 67% above their 2015 levels and 53% higher than the five-year average for this time of the year. Inventories are up because March was much warmer than normal which curbed gas withdrawals to meet heating demand. At the same time, U.S. natural gas production especially output from shale formations remains strong. Looking ahead, U.S. natural gas inventories are expected to be at a record level of more than 4.1 trillion cubic feet at the start of the next winter heating season in November.
Contact/Author: Jonathan Cogan, 202-586-8719
Transcript: http://www.eia.gov/radio/transcript/steo_natural_gas_inventories_04122016.pdf
Length of mp3: 00:00:57
Size of mp3: 0.9 mb
More on this topic: http://www.eia.gov/forecasts/steo/report/

U.S. diesel fuel price continues to increases mp3
Date: March 14, 2016
Description: The U.S. average retail price for on-highway diesel fuel rose to $2.10 a gallon on Monday. That's up 7.8 cents from a week ago, based on the weekly price survey by the U.S. Energy Information Administration. Diesel prices were highest in the West Coast states at 2.29 a gallon, up 6.6 cents from a week ago. Prices were lowest in the Gulf Coast states at 1.99 a gallon, up 8.3 cents.
Contact/Author: Amerine Woodyard, 202-586-1256

Date: March 14, 2016
Description: The U.S. average retail price for regular gasoline rose to $1.96 a gallon on Monday. That's up 12 cents from a week ago, based on the weekly price survey by the U.S. Energy Information Administration. Date: March 9, 2016

Size of mp3: 0.1 mb
More on this topic: http://www.eia.gov/petroleum/heatingoilpropane/
U.S. gasoline price expected to average less than $2 a gallon both this year and next mp3
Date: March 8, 2016
Description: U.S. drivers are now expected to see back-to-back years of annual average gasoline prices below $2 per gallon for the first time in more than a decade. In its latest monthly forecast, the U.S. Energy Information Administration said low oil prices will keep the average annual price for a gallon of regular-grade gasoline at $1.89 this year and at $1.97 in 2017. The last time gasoline averaged less than $2 for two years in row was during 2003 and 2004. The savings for consumers at the pump reflect the impact of cheaper crude oil prices which currently account for about 40 percent of the cost of a gallon of gasoline. Crude oil prices have declined more than 70% since the summer of 2014. Record high U.S. oil inventories along with growing global oil production are expected to keep crude oil prices low.
Contact/Author: Jonathan Cogan, 202-586-8719
Transcript: http://www.eia.gov/radio/transcript/steo_gasoline_price_03082016.pdf
Length of mp3: 00:01:02
Size of mp3: 1.0 mb
More on this topic: http://www.eia.gov/forecasts/steo/report/
Natural gas will account for biggest share of U.S. electricity for first time in 2016 mp3
Date: March 8, 2016
Description: For the first time on an annual basis, the amount of U.S. electricity generated by natural gas-fired power plants is expected to exceed coal-fired generation. In its new monthly forecast, the U.S. Energy Information Administration said 33% of U.S. electricity will come from natural gas this year while 32% will come from coal. The electric power sector's use of coal this year is expected to decline by 29 million short tons or by about 4% because of both mild winter weather and continued strong competition from low-priced natural gas used as an electricity-generating fuel. Record high U.S. natural gas production is pushing down wholesale natural gas prices which recently sank to their lowest levels in more than 17 years. More coal-fired generating units are also scheduled to shut down this year.
Contact/Author: Jonathan Cogan, 202-586-8719
Transcript: http://www.eia.gov/radio/transcript/steo_electricity_generation_03082016.pdf
Length of mp3: 00:00:54
Size of mp3: 0.9 mb
More on this topic: http://www.eia.gov/forecasts/steo/report/
World oil inventories forecast to grow significantly in 2016 and 2017 mp3
Date: March 8, 2016
Description: Global oil inventories are expected to continue strong growth over the next two years which should keep oil prices low. In its new monthly forecast, the U.S. Energy Information Administration said world oil stocks are likely to increase by 1.6 million barrels per day this year and by 600,000 barrels per day next year. The higher forecast for inventory builds are the result of both higher global oil production and less oil demand due to weaker economic growth worldwide. This will delay the rebalancing of supply and demand in the global oil market keeping oil prices low.
Contact/Author: Jonathan Cogan, 202-586-8719
Transcript: http://www.eia.gov/radio/transcript/steo_world_oil_inventories_03082016.pdf
Length of mp3: 00:00:39
Size of mp3: 0.7 mb
More on this topic: http://www.eia.gov/forecasts/steo/report/

U.S. Diesel Fuel Price Falls Under $2 mp3
Date: February 16, 2016
Description: The U.S. average retail price for on-highway diesel fuel fell 2.8 cents from a week ago to $1.98 a gallon on Monday. This marks the first time since 2005 that diesel prices have fallen under 2 dollars, based on the weekly price survey by the U.S. Energy Information Administration. Diesel prices were highest in the Central Atlantic region at 2.20 a gallon, down 2.7 cents from a week ago. Prices were lowest in the Gulf Coast states at 1.86 a gallon, down 3.8 cents.

More on this topic: http://www.eia.gov/petroleum/heatingoilpropane/
Natural gas inventories to remain high at end of winter heating season mp3
Date: February 9, 2016
Description: Despite the jump in natural gas use to meet heating demand during the recent winter storm that walloped the East Coast, total U.S. natural gas inventories remain near 3 trillion cubic feet. That’s about 20 percent higher than at this time last year. In its new monthly forecast, the U.S. Energy Information Administration said that by the end of the winter heating season at the close of March, it expects natural gas inventories will total over 2 trillion cubic feet. That would be 41% higher than at the end of last winter. The high inventory levels reflect warmer weather during December and strong domestic gas production which is expected to reach a record high this year even though production will grow at a slower rate than in recent years.
Contact/Author: Jonathan Cogan, 202-586-8719
Transcript: http://www.eia.gov/radio/transcript/steo_natural_gas_inventories_02092016.pdf
Length of mp3: 00:00:49
Size of mp3: 0.8 mb
More on this topic: http://www.eia.gov/forecasts/steo/report/
East Coast blizzard cuts into gasoline demand, but home electricity demand rises mp3
Date: February 9, 2016
Description: U.S. monthly gasoline consumption declined in January, as the big winter storm that shut down many East Coast cities kept people in their homes and off the road. In its new monthly forecast, the U.S. Energy Information Administration said monthly gasoline consumption dropped 230,000 barrels per day in January compared to year-ago levels and that marked the first year-over-year decline in monthly gasoline use since November 2014. At the same time gasoline inventories rose nearly 23 million barrels the largest January increase in 23 years. The big storm also affected residential electricity demand which was up as many consumers were stuck at home for days until they could dig out of their neighborhoods. However, the boost in home power use was partially offset by the decline in electricity demand from the many closed businesses, schools, and government buildings.
Contact/Author: Jonathan Cogan, 202-586-8719
Transcript: http://www.eia.gov/radio/transcript/steo_gasoline_demand_02092016.pdf
Length of mp3: 00:00:56
Size of mp3: 0.9 mb
More on this topic: http://www.eia.gov/forecasts/steo/report/
Gasoline price to average below $2 in 2016 for first time in 12 years mp3
Date: February 9, 2016
Description: The annual average price for U.S. regular-grade gasoline is expected to fall below $2 per gallon this year for the first time since 2004. In its new monthly forecast, the U.S. Energy Information Administration said drivers will pay on average $1.98 per gallon to fill up at the pump with regular-grade gasoline. EIA expects the monthly average price of gasoline to reach a seven-year low of $1.82 per gallon in February, before rising in the spring when gasoline demand picks up. Lower crude oil prices which have fallen more than 70% since the summer of 2014…are behind the savings for consumers.
Contact/Author: Jonathan Cogan, 202-586-8719
Transcript: http://www.eia.gov/radio/transcript/steo_gasoline_price_02092016.pdf
Length of mp3: 00:00:41
Size of mp3: 0.7 mb

Date: February 8, 2016
Description: The U.S. average retail price for on-highway diesel fuel fell to its lowest level in nearly 11 years to $2.01 a gallon on Monday. That's down 2.3 cents from a week ago, based on the weekly price survey by the U.S. Energy Information Administration. Diesel prices were highest in the West Coast states at 2.24 a gallon, down 3.7 cents from a week ago. Prices were lowest in the Gulf Coast states at 1.90 a gallon, down 2.1 cents.

U.S. diesel fuel prices continue to decrease mp3
Date: January 25, 2016
Description: The U.S. average retail price for on-highway diesel fuel fell to $2.07 a gallon on Monday. That's down 4.1 cents from a week ago, based on the weekly price survey by the U.S. Energy Information Administration.

Date: January 25, 2016
Description: The U.S. average retail price for regular gasoline fell to $1.86 a gallon on Monday. That's down 5.8 cents from a week ago, based on the weekly price survey by the U.S. Energy Information Administration. Household heating bills to be even lower this winter mp3
Date: January 12, 2016
Description: U.S. households will see even lower natural gas and heating oil bills this winter than previously expected the lowest in more than a decade. In its new monthly forecast, the U.S. Energy Information Administration said the average household heating with oil will experience a 41% drop in heating oil expenditures this winter, paying just under $1,100. Meanwhile, households relying primarily on natural gas to stay warm will pay an average $532 this winter. That's down 17% from last winter. Falling crude oil and natural gas prices, along with less heating fuel demand because of warmer-than-normal weather this winter, are the main contributors to lower household heating bills.
Contact/Author: Jonathan Cogan, 202-586-8719
Transcript: http://www.eia.gov/radio/transcript/steo_heating_bills_01122016.pdf
Length of mp3: 00:00:46
Size of mp3: 0.8 mb
More on this topic: http://www.eia.gov/forecasts/steo/report/
Nationwide average gasoline price to fall below $2 a gallon in January mp3
Date: January 12, 2016
Description: The national average price of regular gasoline is expected to drop below $2 per gallon this month and hover near the $2 level through most of this year, as lower crude oil prices translate into more savings for consumers at the pump. In its new monthly forecast, the U.S. Energy Information Administration said the retail price for regular-grade gasoline averages $1.90 per gallon in February. That's the lowest level in seven years. Gasoline prices are expected to rise during the spring and summer, when gasoline demand picks up and refiners switch over to making more expensive summer-grade gasoline needed to keep the air cleaner during the summer smog season. Still, EIA expects gasoline prices to remain well below recent prices over the 2010 to 2014 period, with the pump price averaging $2.03 per gallon this year and $2.21 in 2017.
Contact/Author: Jonathan Cogan, 202-586-8719
Transcript: http://www.eia.gov/radio/transcript/steo_gasoline_price_01122016.pdf
Length of mp3: 00:00:56
Size of mp3: 0.9 mb
More on this topic: http://www.eia.gov/forecasts/steo/report/

Description: The U.S. average retail price for regular gasoline fell to $2.06 a gallon on Monday. That's down 3 1/2 cents from a week ago, based on the weekly price survey by the U.S. Energy Information Administration.
Contact/Author: Amerine Woodyard, 202-586-1256
Transcript: http://www.eia.gov/radio/transcript/gasoline_price_11302015_short.pdf
Length of mp3: 00:00:16
Size of mp3: 0.3 mb
More on this topic: http://www.eia.gov/petroleum/gasdiesel/
Residential heating oil price decreases mp3
Date: November 25, 2015
Description: The average retail price for home heating oil fell 2.3 cents from a week ago to $2.38 per gallon. That's down 99 cents from a year ago, based on the residential heating fuel survey by the U.S. Energy Information Administration.
Contact/Author: Marcela Rourk, 202-586-4412
Transcript: http://www.eia.gov/radio/transcript/heating_oil_price_11252015.pdf

U.S. gasoline prices decrease (long version) mp3
Date: November 23, 2015
Description: The U.S. average retail price for regular gasoline fell to $2.09 a gallon on Monday. That's down 8.4 cents from a week ago, based on the weekly price survey by the U.S. Energy Information Administration. Pump prices were highest in the West Coast states at 2.58 a gallon, down 5.7 cents from a week ago. Prices were lowest in the Gulf Coast states at 1.85 a gallon, down 7.2 cents.
Contact/Author: Amerine Woodyard, 202-586-1256
Transcript: http://www.eia.gov/radio/transcript/gasoline_price_11232015_long.pdf

Residential heating oil price decreases mp3
Date: November 18, 2015
Description: The average retail price for home heating oil fell 3.1 cents from a week ago to $2.40 per gallon. That's down 99 cents from a year ago, based on the residential heating fuel survey by the U.S. Energy Information Administration. Heating oil prices in the New England region fell to $2.35 per gallon, down 2.7 cents from last week, and down 98 cents from a year ago.
Contact/Author: Marcela Rourk, 202-586-4412

Date: November 18, 2015
Description: The average retail price for propane is $1.94 per gallon, up 2 cents from last week, based on the residential heating fuel survey by the U.S. Energy Information Administration. Propane prices in the Midwest region averaged $1.42 per gallon, up 1 cent from last week, and down 52.8 cents from a year ago.

U.S. gasoline consumption highest in 8 years mp3
Date: November 10, 2015
Description: U.S. gasoline consumption this year is expected to be at the highest level since the record fuel demand seen back in 2007 as lower gasoline prices and more people finding jobs means more sales at the gasoline pump. In its new monthly forecast, the U.S. Energy Information Administration said gasoline consumption increased by 2.7% during the first eight months of 2015 and should rise by an average of 190,000 barrels per day this year to 9.1 million barrels per day. That would be the highest level since the record 9.3 million barrels per day set in 2007. Gasoline demand growth is expected to slow to 20,000 barrels per day next year as drivers continue the long-term trend of traveling in more fuel-efficient vehicles.
Contact/Author: Jonathan Cogan, 202-586-8719
Transcript: http://www.eia.gov/radio/transcript/steo_gasoline_demand_11102015.pdf
Length of mp3: 00:00:52
Size of mp3: 0.8 mb
More on this topic: http://www.eia.gov/forecasts/steo/report/
U.S. natural gas inventories at record levels mp3
Date: November 10, 2015
Description: U.S. natural gas inventories at the end of October tied the all-time record high and inventories could climb to 4 trillion cubic feet in November for the first time. In its new monthly forecast, the U.S. Energy Information Administration said weekly injections of natural gas into storage may continue into November, after inventories at the close of October matched the record high of just over 3.9 trillion cubic feet. High inventories, along with rising natural production and expected warmer winter weather, should lead to lower residential natural gas prices this winter. This could cut the expenditures for households that heat primarily with natural gas by about 13% this winter compared to last winter.
Contact/Author: Jonathan Cogan, 202-586-8719
Transcript: http://www.eia.gov/radio/transcript/steo_natural_gas_inventories_11102015.pdf
Length of mp3: 00:00:48
Size of mp3: 0.8 mb
More on this topic: http://www.eia.gov/forecasts/steo/report/
Non-OPEC oil production set to decline for first time since 2008 mp3
Date: November 10, 2015
Description: Total oil production from countries outside of OPEC, the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries, is expected to decline next year for the first time since 2008. In its new monthly forecast, the U.S. Energy Information Administration said it expects non-OPEC oil production to grow by 1.1 million barrels per day this year and then decline by 300,000 barrels per day next year. As a result, the rate of growth in world oil inventories is expected to slow from over 1.5 million barrels per day this year to 400,000 barrels per day in 2016.
Contact/Author: Jonathan Cogan, 202-586-8719
Transcript: http://www.eia.gov/radio/transcript/steo_non_opec_oil_production_11102015.pdf
Length of mp3: 00:00:40
Size of mp3: 0.6 mb
More on this topic: http://www.eia.gov/forecasts/steo/report/

U.S. diesel fuel prices continue to decrease mp3
Date: November 2, 2015
Description: The U.S. average retail price for on-highway diesel fuel fell to $2.49 a gallon on Monday. That's down 1.3 cents from a week ago, based on the weekly price survey by the U.S. Energy Information Administration. Diesel prices were highest in the West Coast states at 2.70 a gallon, down 6-tenths of a penny from a week ago. Prices were lowest in the Gulf Coast states at 2.29 a gallon, down 9-tenths of a penny.

U.S. average gasoline prices falling to near $2 in December mp3
Date: October 6, 2015
Description: U.S. retail gasoline prices are expected to continue falling over the next few months, dropping to a national average near $2 per gallon in December. In its new forecast, the U.S. Energy Information Administration said high gasoline production, cheaper winter-grade gasoline, and lower gasoline demand following this summer's peak driving season will contribute to savings at the pump for consumers. The monthly average price for gasoline is expected to be $2.03 per gallon in December, which would the lowest price for the month since 2008. Average prices in some regions of the country are expected to be below $2 a gallon in December.
Contact/Author: Jonathan Cogan, 202-586-8719
Transcript: http://www.eia.gov/radio/transcript/steo_gasoline_prices_10062015.pdf
Length of mp3: 00:00:42
Size of mp3: 0.7 mb
More on this topic: http://www.eia.gov/forecasts/steo/report/
Natural gas inventories heading to record levels at start of winter heating season mp3
Date: October 6, 2015
Description: U.S. natural gas inventories are expected to be at record levels to start the winter heating season. In its new forecast, the U.S. Energy Information Administration said the amount of natural gas stored underground should total almost 4 trillion cubic feet by the beginning of November, reflecting record high natural gas production. Inventories could go even higher if heating demand is not strong during October.
Contact/Author: Jonathan Cogan, 202-586-8719
Transcript: http://www.eia.gov/radio/transcript/steo_natural_gas_inventories_10062015.pdf
Length of mp3: 00:00:27
Size of mp3: 0.5 mb
More on this topic: http://www.eia.gov/forecasts/steo/report/
Household heating bills expected to be lower this winter mp3
Date: October 6, 2015
Description: U.S. consumers are expected to pay less this winter on their home heating bills because of lower oil and natural gas prices and projected milder temperatures than last winter. In its new forecast, the U.S. Energy Information Administration said households that rely on heating oil which are mainly located in the Northeast will pay the lowest heating expenditures in 9 years down 25% from last winter as consumers are expected to save about $460 this heating season. Propane users most of which are located in the Midwest will pay about 21% less, a decrease of around $320 while households that heat with natural gas will pay 10%, or about $60 less than last winter. Households that rely on electric heat will see their average bill decline by about $30, or 3% less.
Contact/Author: Jonathan Cogan, 202-586-8719
Transcript: http://www.eia.gov/radio/transcript/steo_household_heating_10062015.pdf
Length of mp3: 00:00:53
Size of mp3: 0.9 mb
More on this topic: http://www.eia.gov/forecasts/steo/report/
U.S. diesel fuel price increases for the first time in a month mp3
Date: October 5, 2015
Description: The U.S. average retail price for on-highway diesel fuel rose for the first time in a month to $2.49 a gallon on Monday. That's up 1.6 cents from a week ago, based on the weekly price survey by the U.S. Energy Information Administration.

U.S. diesel fuel prices continue to decrease mp3
Date: September 28, 2015
Description: The U.S. average retail price for on-highway diesel fuel fell to $2.48 a gallon on Monday. That's down 1.7 cents from a week ago, based on the weekly price survey by the U.S. Energy Information Administration. Diesel prices were highest in the West Coast states at 2.69 a gallon, down 2.2 cents from a week ago. Prices were lowest in the Gulf Coast states at 2.32 a gallon, down 1.7 cents.

Date: September 28, 2015
Description: The U.S. average retail price for regular gasoline fell to $2.32 a gallon on Monday. That's down half a penny from a week ago, based on the weekly price survey by the U.S. Energy Information Administration. Pump prices were highest in the West Coast states at 2.84 a gallon, down 7 1/2 cents from a week ago. Prices were lowest in the Gulf Coast states at 2.02 a gallon, down a penny.

U.S. gasoline price to continue falling through December on low oil prices mp3
Date: September 9, 2015
Description: U.S. drivers will continue to see the effects of low crude oil prices as gasoline prices are expected to decline through the rest of this year. In its new forecast, the U.S. Energy Information Administration said the monthly retail price for regular-grade gasoline is expected to drop from a monthly average of $2.64 per gallon in August to $2.03 in December. The recent drop in the price of crude oil which currently accounts for almost half of what consumers pay at the gasoline pump reflects market concerns about weak global oil demand growth, the possibility of more oil exports from Iran, and rising world oil inventories. U.S. drivers this past Labor Day paid the lowest price for gasoline in 11 years during the heavily traveled holiday weekend.
Contact/Author: Jonathan Cogan, 202-586-8719
Transcript: http://www.eia.gov/radio/transcript/steo_gasoline_price_09092015.pdf
Length of mp3: 00:00:52
Size of mp3: 0.9 mb
More on this topic: http://www.eia.gov/forecasts/steo/report/
U.S. oil production expected to decline over next year, rebounding in late 2016 mp3
Date: September 9, 2015
Description: U.S. monthly crude oil production is expected to decline through the middle of next year in response to low prices. In its new forecast, the U.S. Energy Information Administration said U.S. crude oil production which averaged 9.4 million barrels per day during the first half of this year is expected to decline through August 2016 to 8.6 million barrels per day. However, U.S. oil production is expected to begin rising in late 2016 climbing back to 9 million barrels per day during the fourth quarter of next year as the forecast for oil prices begins to increase. Low oil prices are making some production less profitable with estimated U.S. oil output during August alone down 140,000 barrels per day from a month earlier. EIA is now able to better track changes in U.S. oil production by directly surveying oil producers in the states that account for more than 90% of the country's total oil output
Contact/Author: Jonathan Cogan, 202-586-8719
Transcript: http://www.eia.gov/radio/transcript/steo_crude_oil_production_09092015.pdf
Length of mp3: 00:01:00
Size of mp3: 0.9 mb
More on this topic: http://www.eia.gov/forecasts/steo/report/

U.S. consumers to pay more to stay cool this summer mp3
Date: June 9, 2015
Description: In its new forecast, the U.S. Energy Information Administration said the typical household will pay $412 for electricity during the combined months of June, July, and August. That's almost 5% more than last summer. Government weather forecasters predict temperatures this summer will be much warmer than last year's mild summer. The warmer temperatures are expected to lead to a 2.6% increase in residential electricity use to meet air conditioning demand which along with a 2.1% increase in the average retail price for electricity means consumers will pay more to stay cool.
Contact/Author: Jonathan Cogan, 202-586-8719
Transcript: http://www.eia.gov/radio/transcript/steo_electricity_bills_06092015.pdf
Length of mp3: 00:00:39
Size of mp3: 0.9 mb
More on this topic: http://www.eia.gov/forecasts/steo/report/
Builds in U.S. natural gas storage running above five-year average mp3
Date: June 9, 2015
Description: The amount of natural gas put into underground storage since the beginning of the so-called "injection season" in April has been above the five-year average by a wide margin. In its new forecast, the U.S. Energy Information Administration said natural gas inventories, which are running more than 50% above year ago levels, are on track to reach almost 4 trillion cubic feet by the end of October which marks the start of the heating season. Rising natural gas production is contributing to the strong build in inventories with monthly gas output expected to set a record during July. The amount of natural gas inventories added to storage during the last week of May was the largest in more than a decade.
Contact/Author: Jonathan Cogan, 202-586-8719
Transcript: http://www.eia.gov/radio/transcript/steo_natural_gas_storage_06092015.pdf
Length of mp3: 00:00:43
Size of mp3: 0.9 mb
More on this topic: http://www.eia.gov/forecasts/steo/report/
Low oil prices cut less into U.S. oil production mp3
Date: June 9, 2015
Description: U.S. crude oil production has been more resilient to lower oil prices since mid-2014 than many had expected. In its new forecast, the U.S. Energy Information Administration estimates domestic oil production averaged 9.6 million barrels per day in May the highest monthly output since 1972 despite a 60% drop in the number of rigs drilling for oil since last October. Output is up because producers are completing wells already drilled and those wells have higher initial production rates. High oil production is reducing U.S net oil imports, which are forecast to account for 21% of demand next year. That's the lowest level since 1969.
Contact/Author: Jonathan Cogan, 202-586-8719
Transcript: http://www.eia.gov/radio/transcript/steo_oil_prices_06092015.pdf
Length of mp3: 00:00:45
Size of mp3: 0.9 mb
More on this topic: http://www.eia.gov/forecasts/steo/report/

Average household expected to save $675 at the pump in 2015 mp3
Date: May 12, 2015
Description: Although retail gasoline prices have risen in recent weeks. U.S. consumers are still expected to save about $675 per household in motor fuel costs this year. In its new monthly forecast, the U.S. Energy Information Administration says the average pump price for regular grade gasoline in 2015 will be $2.43 per gallon. That's about 93 cents lower than last year's average. The savings for consumers will be even bigger during the heavier-traveled summer driving period when regular gasoline is expected to average $2.55 a gallon, down $1.04 from last summer.
Contact/Author: Jonathan Cogan, 202-586-8719
Transcript: http://www.eia.gov/radio/transcript/steo_gasoline_price_05122015.pdf
Length of mp3: 00:00:59
Size of mp3: 0.9 mb
More on this topic: http://www.eia.gov/forecasts/steo/report/
High natural gas output and inventories contribute to lower prices mp3
Date: May 12, 2015
Description: High natural gas production and ample gas inventories are expected to keep natural gas prices relatively low for the rest of 2015. In its new monthly forecast, the U.S. Energy Information Administration says that while expected production growth is slowing from last year's torrid pace, domestic natural gas production in 2015 is still expected to be almost 6 percent above the 2014 level. Higher production has pushed U.S. natural gas inventories about 1 trillion cubic feet above a year ago. Continued strong output is also expected to keep natural gas prices below $3 per million Btu through August and less than $4 through the end of the year.
Contact/Author: Jonathan Cogan, 202-586-8719
Transcript: http://www.eia.gov/radio/transcript/steo_natural_gas_production_05122015.pdf
Length of mp3: 00:00:44
Size of mp3: 0.7 mb
More on this topic: http://www.eia.gov/forecasts/steo/report/
U.S. oil production forecast update reflects lower rig counts mp3
Date: May 12, 2015
Description: Lower oil prices and fewer rigs drilling for crude oil are expected to slow U.S. oil production growth this year and in 2016. U.S. crude oil production is still expected to average 9.2 million barrels per day this year. That's up half a million barrels per day from last year and the highest output level in more than four decades. A substantial part of the year-over-year increase reflects rapid production growth throughout 2014. Expected production in 2015 is only one hundred thousand barrels per day above the level of production in the last quarter of 2014. Oil production is expected to be about the same next year as in 2015.
Contact/Author: Jonathan Cogan, 202-586-8719
Transcript: http://www.eia.gov/radio/transcript/steo_crude_oil_production_05122015.pdf
Length of mp3: 00:00:44
Size of mp3: 0.7 mb
More on this topic: http://www.eia.gov/forecasts/steo/report/

Date: May 11, 2015
Description: The U.S. average retail price for on-highway diesel fuel rose to $2.88 a gallon on Monday. That's up 2.4 cents from a week ago, based on the weekly price survey by the U.S. Energy Information Administration. Diesel prices were highest in the Central Atlantic region at 3.15 a gallon, up 1.8 cents from a week ago. Prices were lowest in the Midwest states at 2.75 a gallon, up 3.3 cents.

Description: The U.S. average retail price for regular gasoline fell to $2.41 a gallon on Monday. That's down half a penny from a week ago, based on the weekly price survey by the U.S. Energy Information Administration. Pump prices were highest in the West Coast states at 2.92 a gallon, down 3.2 cents from a week ago. Prices were lowest in the Gulf Coast states at 2.19 a gallon, up half a penny.
Contact/Author: Amerine Woodyard, 202-586-1256
Transcript: http://www.eia.gov/radio/transcript/gasoline_price_04132015_long.pdf
Length of mp3: 00:00:30
Size of mp3: 0.5 mb
More on this topic: http://www.eia.gov/petroleum/gasdiesel/
U.S. gasoline prices remain flat (Short version) mp3
Date: April 13, 2015
Description: The U.S. average retail price for regular gasoline fell to $2.41 a gallon on Monday. That's down half a penny from a week ago, based on the weekly price survey by the U.S. Energy Information Administration.

Size of mp3: 0.3 mb
More on this topic: http://www.eia.gov/petroleum/gasdiesel/
U.S. drivers to see big savings at the gasoline pump this summer mp3
Date: April 7, 2015
Description: U.S. consumers are expected to pay the lowest average price for gasoline in six years during this summer's driving season, mostly because of lower crude oil costs. In its new forecast, the U.S. Energy Information Administration said the price for regular gasoline should average $2.45 per gallon this summer. That's down more than a dollar from the $3.59 per gallon seen last summer, and the cheapest average summer pump price since 2009.
Contact/Author: Jonathan Cogan, 202-586-8719
Transcript: http://www.eia.gov/radio/transcript/steo_gasoline_price_04072015.pdf
Length of mp3: 00:00:54
Size of mp3: 0.9 mb
More on this topic: http://www.eia.gov/forecasts/steo/report/
U.S. power producers using more natural gas in 2015 mp3
Date: April 7, 2015
Description: U.S. electric power producers are increasing their use of natural gas and burning less coal for generating electricity. In its new forecast, the U.S. Energy Information Administration said natural gas-fired generation is expected to produce 30% of U.S. electricity this year. That's up from 27% during 2014.
Contact/Author: Jonathan Cogan, 202-586-8719
Transcript: http://www.eia.gov/radio/transcript/steo_electricity_generation_04072015.pdf
Length of mp3: 00:00:43
Size of mp3: 0.7 mb
More on this topic: http://www.eia.gov/forecasts/steo/report/
U.S. natural gas inventories at end of winter higher than last year mp3
Date: April 7, 2015
Description: Despite recent cold temperatures in some parts of the country, U.S. natural gas inventories ended the winter heating season in better shape than last year. In its new forecast, the U.S. Energy Information Administration said natural gas inventories near the end of March were 75% higher compared with the same period in 2014. That sets up adequate supplies for gas-fired power plants this summer to meet electric cooling needs of households and businesses.
Contact/Author: Jonathan Cogan, 202-586-8719
Transcript: http://www.eia.gov/radio/transcript/steo_natural_gas_inventories_04072015.pdf

Heating oil and propane households bills to be lower this winter despite recent cold spell mp3
Date: March 10, 2015
Description: Despite the recent cold weather, households that use heating oil or propane as their main space heating fuel are still expected to have lower heating bills compared with last winter. In its new monthly forecast, the U.S. Energy Information Administration said the average household that uses heating oil will spend $1,780 this winter that's about $570 less than last winter. Those savings reflect lower crude oil prices. Propane prices are lower this winter thanks mainly to ample supplies. That's expected to help reduce costs for Northeast propane users by 18 percent while Midwest households will spend 32 percent less on propane.
Contact/Author: Jonathan Cogan, 202-586-8719
Transcript: http://www.eia.gov/radio/transcript/steo_winter_heating_outlook_03102015.pdf
Length of mp3: 00:00:45
Size of mp3: 0.7 mb
More on this topic: http://www.eia.gov/forecasts/steo/report/
Average U.S. household to spend $710 less on gasoline during 2015 mp3
Date: March 10, 2015
Description: Even with the recent increases in gasoline prices, the average U.S. household is still expected save $710 in gasoline costs this year compared with what was paid at the pump in 2014. In its new monthly forecast, the U.S. Energy Information Administration said the national average price for regular gasoline is expected to be $2.39 per gallon this year. That's almost $1 less than the $3.36 average in 2014. Lower crude oil prices this year which are forecast to be about 40 percent less than last year are the main contributor to the savings at the pump. The price of oil accounts for more than half of the retail price of gasoline.
Contact/Author: Jonathan Cogan, 202-586-8719
Transcript: http://www.eia.gov/radio/transcript/steo_gasoline_price_03102015.pdf
Length of mp3: 00:00:46
Size of mp3: 0.7 mb
More on this topic: http://www.eia.gov/forecasts/steo/report/
Record U.S. oil inventories to continue increasing over next two months mp3
Date: March 10, 2015
Description: U.S. commercial crude oil inventories which are already at the highest level since 1930 are expected to continue growing over the next two months. Crude oil stocks increased by an average of over 500,000 barrels per day during the last five months climbing to 444 million barrels at the end of February. In its new monthly forecast, the U.S. Energy Information Administration said the increase in oil inventories will moderate as refineries ramp up their processing of crude oil into petroleum products in the second quarter and domestic oil production slows. U.S. crude oil storage capacity is now about 62% full compared with 48% a year ago.
Contact/Author: Jonathan Cogan, 202-586-8719
Transcript: http://www.eia.gov/radio/transcript/steo_crude_oil_production_03102015.pdf
Length of mp3: 00:00:45
Size of mp3: 0.7 mb
More on this topic: http://www.eia.gov/forecasts/steo/report/

Gasoline price forecast to stay below $3 a gallon in 2015 mp3
Date: February 10, 2015
Description: The national average pump price of gasoline is expected to stay below $3 per gallon during 2015. In its new monthly forecast, the U.S. Energy Information Administration said the retail price for regular gasoline should average $2.33 per gallon this year. The price of gasoline increased in early February after falling for 17 weeks in a row. But gasoline prices will continue to remain low in 2015 when compared with pump prices in recent years because of expected low crude oil costs. As a result, the average U.S. household is expected to save $750 in gasoline costs this year compared with 2014.
Contact/Author: Jonathan Cogan, 202-586-8719
Transcript: http://www.eia.gov/radio/transcript/steo_gasoline_price_02102015.pdf
Length of mp3: 00:00:42
Size of mp3: 0.6 mb
More on this topic: http://www.eia.gov/forecasts/steo/report/
High oil production continues to cut U.S. oil imports mp3
Date: February 10, 2015
Description: High U.S. crude oil production will help further reduce America's reliance on oil imports during the next two years. In its monthly forecast, the U.S. Energy Information Administration said it expects the share of U.S. petroleum demand met by net imports to decline to 22% this year and fall to 20% in 2016 which would be the lowest level since 1968. Net petroleum imports met 60 percent of U.S. consumption just 10 years ago. Growing domestic oil production has contributed to a significant decline in petroleum liquid imports and is expected to average 9.5 million barrels per day next year. That would be the highest annual output level since 1970.
Contact/Author: Jonathan Cogan, 202-586-8719
Transcript: http://www.eia.gov/radio/transcript/steo_crude_oil_production_02102015.pdf
Length of mp3: 00:00:46
Size of mp3: 0.7 mb
More on this topic: http://www.eia.gov/forecasts/steo/report/
Oil inventories in industrialized countries to reach record high at end of 2015 mp3
Date: February 10, 2015
Description: The amount of year-end oil inventories held in industrialized countries is expected to be the highest on record in 2015. In its monthly forecast, the U.S. Energy Information Administration said it expects commercial oil inventories in the United States and other industrialized countries to total 2.83 billion barrels at the end of this year almost 90 million barrels more than at the end of 2014. Global oil production is expected to continue to exceed oil demand, resulting in record-high oil inventories. High oil inventories are a key contributor to low oil prices.
Contact/Author: Jonathan Cogan, 202-586-8719
Transcript: http://www.eia.gov/radio/transcript/steo_oil_inventories_02102015.pdf
Length of mp3: 00:00:42
Size of mp3: 0.6 mb
More on this topic: http://www.eia.gov/forecasts/steo/report/

Falling crude prices to slow U.S. oil production growth in 2015 mp3
Date: January 13, 2015
Description: U.S. crude oil production is expected to increase again this year, but lower crude prices will slow the growth in output. In its new forecast, the U.S. Energy Information Administration said domestic crude oil production should average 9.3 million barrels per day in 2015. On-shore production in the Lower 48-states is expected to grow in the early part of the year, before declining in the second half. Production for the federal offshore region is projected to rise and Alaskan production is expected to fall. Production in both of those areas is less sensitive to short-term price movements than is onshore production. In the Lower 48 states. Many oil companies have cut back on their exploration drilling in response to falling crude prices and are concentrating their drilling activities in established shale areas that already have productive wells.
Contact/Author: Jonathan Cogan, 202-586-8719
Transcript: http://www.eia.gov/radio/transcript/steo_crude_oil_production_01132015.pdf
Length of mp3: 00:01:11
Size of mp3: 1.1 mb
More on this topic: http://www.eia.gov/forecasts/steo/report/
U.S. households to pay an average $750 less for gasoline in 2015 mp3
Date: January 13, 2015
Description: In its new forecast, the U.S. Energy Information Administration expects the average U.S. household to spend $750 less for gasoline this year compared to 2014. The price for regular gasoline this year is forecast to average $2.33 per gallon. The average pump price is expected to rise to $2.72 per gallon in 2016.
Contact/Author: Jonathan Cogan, 202-586-8719
Transcript: http://www.eia.gov/radio/transcript/steo_gasoline_spending_01132015.pdf
Length of mp3: 00:00:33
Size of mp3: 0.5 mb
More on this topic: http://www.eia.gov/forecasts/steo/report/

Residential heating oil price decreases mp3
Date: December 31, 2014
Description: The average retail price for home heating oil fell 3.6 cents from a week ago to $3.04 per gallon. That's down 99.4 cents from a year ago, based on the residential heating fuel survey by the U.S. Energy Information Administration. Heating oil prices in the New England region fell to $3.01 per gallon, down 3.6 cents from last week, and down $1.01 from a year ago
Contact/Author: Marcela Rourk, 202-586-4412
Transcript: http://www.eia.gov/radio/transcript/heating_oil_price_12312014.pdf
Length of mp3: 00:00:30
Size of mp3: 0.5 mb
More on this topic: http://www.eia.gov/petroleum/heatingoilpropane/
Residential propane price decreases mp3
Date: December 31, 2014
Description: The average retail price for propane is $2.37 per gallon, down 1.3 cents from last week, based on the residential heating fuel survey by the U.S. Energy Information Administration. Propane prices in the Midwest region averaged $1.93 per gallon, down 3-tenths of a cent from last week, and down 39.6 cents from a year ago.
Contact/Author: Marcela Rourk, 202-586-4412
Transcript: http://www.eia.gov/radio/transcript/propane_price_12312014.pdf
Length of mp3: 00:00:27
Size of mp3: 0.4 mb
More on this topic: http://www.eia.gov/petroleum/heatingoilpropane/
U.S. diesel fuel price continues to decrease mp3
Date: December 29, 2014
Description: The U.S. average retail price for on-highway diesel fuel fell to $3.21 a gallon on Monday. That's down 6.8 cents from a week ago, based on the weekly price survey by the U.S. Energy Information Administration. Diesel prices were highest in the New England region at 3.37 a gallon, down 6 cents from a week ago. Prices were lowest in the Gulf Coast region at 3.12 a gallon, down 5.4 cents.
Contact/Author: Amerine Woodyard, 202-586-1256
Transcript: http://www.eia.gov/radio/transcript/diesel_price_12292014.pdf
Length of mp3: 00:00:29
Size of mp3: 0.5 mb
More on this topic: http://www.eia.gov/petroleum/gasdiesel/
U.S. gasoline prices decrease to lowest level since May 2009 (long version) mp3
Date: December 29, 2014
Description: The U.S. average retail price for regular gasoline fell to its lowest level since May 2009 to $2.30 a gallon on Monday. That's down 10.4 cents from a week ago, based on the weekly price survey by the U.S. Energy Information Administration. Pump prices were highest in the West Coast states at 2.62 a gallon, down 8.2 cents from a week ago. Prices were lowest in the Gulf Coast region at 2.07 a gallon, down 10.3 cents.
Contact/Author: Amerine Woodyard, 202-586-1256
Transcript: http://www.eia.gov/radio/transcript/gasoline_price_12292014_long.pdf
Length of mp3: 00:00:32
Size of mp3: 0.5 mb
More on this topic: http://www.eia.gov/petroleum/gasdiesel/

Date: December 24, 2014

Propane prices in the Midwest region averaged $1.93 per gallon, down one cent from last week, and down 35.5 cents from a year ago.

U.S. diesel fuel price falls to lowest level in four years mp3
Date: December 22, 2014
Description: The U.S. average retail price for on-highway diesel fuel fell to $3.28 a gallon on Monday. That's down 13.8 cents from a week ago, based on the weekly price survey by the U.S. Energy Information Administration. Diesel prices were highest in the New England region at 3.43 a gallon, down 4.2 cents from a week ago. Prices were lowest in the Gulf Coast region at 3.18 a gallon, down 15.3 cents.

Date: December 22, 2014
Description: The U.S. average retail price for regular gasoline fell to $2.40 a gallon on Monday.
